title: Munno Para sexual assault: Police search continues male attacker
text:
A woman wearing headphones was oblivious to a man who hit her on the head with a “hammer-like weapon” before sexually assaulting her in the bushes of a Munno Para park, police say.

Residents say the disturbing attack has struck fear into the community and should make females reconsider walking alone.

The unsuspecting young woman was going for a morning walk on a path through a wetlands area near Ramsar Rd, where she was hit, taken to the bushes and sexually assaulted about 7am on Friday.

Her attacker – who spoke in a foreign language and also in English but with an accent – fled in an unknown direction, while the woman sought help at a nearby residence before she was treated at hospital.

Special Crimes Investigation Branch officer-in-charge Detective Chief Inspector Richard Lambert said the victim was wearing headphones and did not hear the man approaching her.

media_camera The crime scene at Munno Para where a woman was sexually assaulted in a wetlands area.

Chief-Insp Lambert said the woman was hit with a “hammer-like weapon”, possibly a mallet. “(The attacker), in my view, there was some level of planning. He was carrying a weapon” he said.

Chief-Insp Lambert said forensic evidence was found at the scene and detectives were following positive leads.

He said police would examine CCTV footage, while State Emergency Service crews and divers will search nearby wetland for the weapon tomorrow.

Chief-Insp Lambert said concerned locals should consider not being by themselves when walking in the area.

“You need to be aware of what’s around you. People who wear earphones or headphones … may not be aware of their surroundings because they’re not listening to the things that are happening,” he said. Mother-of-two Danielle Beverdam said the incident was a wake-up call for others who enjoyed the park.

“It’s horrible, you shouldn’t have to be worried about being attacked while you’re out on a morning walk,” she said

Local George Barnett, 64, said all women should rethink walking alone in the area. “It’s awful, I would never let a woman walk around here again on her own,” he said.

The man was described as 170cm tall, with a tanned complexion, of medium build, and wearing a black mask across the lower half of his face, along with a hooded jumper and dark-coloured pants.

Anyone who may have witnessed the incident, saw a man matching the description, or has dashcam footage of the area, should contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.
description: A woman was attacked from behind while wearing headphones in a frightening sex assault thats left a northern suburbs community in fear.
